commitSHA.title:
The Git digest of the commit this binary was built at.
+optional

date.title:
A human-readable string representing when the binary was built.
+optional

dev.title:
Indicates whether this is a development build (true) or an official release (false).
+optional

corev1alpha1TiltBuild.description: Information about the running tilt binary.

checkUpdates.title:
Whether version updates have been enabled/disabled from the Tiltfile.
+optional

corev1alpha1VersionSettings.description: Information about how the Tilt binary handles updates.

Raw.description: Raw is the underlying serialization of this object.

v1FieldsV1.description:
FieldsV1 stores a set of fields in a data structure like a Trie, in JSON format.

Each key is either a '.' representing the field itself, and will always map to an empty set,
or a string representing a sub-field or item. The string will follow one of these four formats:
'f:<name>', where <name> is the name of a field in a struct, or key in a map
'v:<value>', where <value> is the exact json formatted value of a list item
'i:<index>', where <index> is position of a item in a list
'k:<keys>', where <keys> is a map of  a list item's key fields to their unique values
If a key maps to an empty Fields value, the field that key represents is part of the set.

The exact format is defined in sigs.k8s.io/structured-merge-diff
+protobuf.options.(gogoproto.goproto_stringer)=false

manager.description: Manager is an identifier of the workflow managing these fields.

operation.description:
Operation is the type of operation which lead to this ManagedFieldsEntry being created.
The only valid values for this field are 'Apply' and 'Update'.

apiVersion.description:
APIVersion defines the version of this resource that this field set
applies to. The format is "group/version" just like the top-level
APIVersion field. It is necessary to track the version of a field
set because it cannot be automatically converted.

time.title:
Time is timestamp of when these fields were set. It should always be empty if Operation is 'Apply'
+optional

fieldsType.title:
FieldsType is the discriminator for the different fields format and version.
There is currently only one possible value: "FieldsV1"

fieldsV1.title:
FieldsV1 holds the first JSON version format as described in the "FieldsV1" type.
+optional

v1ManagedFieldsEntry.description:
ManagedFieldsEntry is a workflow-id, a FieldSet and the group version of the resource
that the fieldset applies to.

seconds.description:
Represents seconds of UTC time since Unix epoch
1970-01-01T00:00:00Z. Must be from 0001-01-01T00:00:00Z to
9999-12-31T23:59:59Z inclusive.

nanos.description:
Non-negative fractions of a second at nanosecond resolution. Negative
second values with fractions must still have non-negative nanos values
that count forward in time. Must be from 0 to 999,999,999
inclusive. This field may be limited in precision depending on context.

v1MicroTime.description:
MicroTime is version of Time with microsecond level precision.

+protobuf.options.marshal=false
+protobuf.as=Timestamp
+protobuf.options.(gogoproto.goproto_stringer)=false

name.title:
Name must be unique within a namespace. Is required when creating resources, although
some resources may allow a client to request the generation of an appropriate name
automatically. Name is primarily intended for creation idempotence and configuration
definition.
Cannot be updated.
More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#names
+optional

generateName.description:
GenerateName is an optional prefix, used by the server, to generate a unique
name ONLY IF the Name field has not been provided.
If this field is used, the name returned to the client will be different
than the name passed. This value will also be combined with a unique suffix.
The provided value has the same validation rules as the Name field,
and may be truncated by the length of the suffix required to make the value
unique on the server.

If this field is specified and the generated name exists, the server will
NOT return a 409 - instead, it will either return 201 Created or 500 with Reason
ServerTimeout indicating a unique name could not be found in the time allotted, and the client
should retry (optionally after the time indicated in the Retry-After header).

Applied only if Name is not specified.
More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#idempotency
+optional

namespace.description:
Namespace defines the space within which each name must be unique. An empty namespace is
equivalent to the "default" namespace, but "default" is the canonical representation.
Not all objects are required to be scoped to a namespace - the value of this field for
those objects will be empty.

Must be a DNS_LABEL.
Cannot be updated.
More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/namespaces
+optional

selfLink.description:
SelfLink is a URL representing this object.
Populated by the system.
Read-only.

DEPRECATED
Kubernetes will stop propagating this field in 1.20 release and the field is planned
to be removed in 1.21 release.
+optional

uid.description:
UID is the unique in time and space value for this object. It is typically generated by
the server on successful creation of a resource and is not allowed to change on PUT
operations.

Populated by the system.
Read-only.
More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#uids
+optional

resourceVersion.description:
An opaque value that represents the internal version of this object that can
be used by clients to determine when objects have changed. May be used for optimistic
concurrency, change detection, and the watch operation on a resource or set of resources.
Clients must treat these values as opaque and passed unmodified back to the server.
They may only be valid for a particular resource or set of resources.

Populated by the system.
Read-only.
Value must be treated as opaque by clients and .
More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#concurrency-control-and-consistency
+optional

generation.title:
A sequence number representing a specific generation of the desired state.
Populated by the system. Read-only.
+optional

creationTimestamp.description:
CreationTimestamp is a timestamp representing the server time when this object was
created. It is not guaranteed to be set in happens-before order across separate operations.
Clients may not set this value. It is represented in RFC3339 form and is in UTC.

Populated by the system.
Read-only.
Null for lists.
More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#metadata
+optional

deletionTimestamp.description:
DeletionTimestamp is RFC 3339 date and time at which this resource will be deleted. This
field is set by the server when a graceful deletion is requested by the user, and is not
directly settable by a client. The resource is expected to be deleted (no longer visible
from resource lists, and not reachable by name) after the time in this field, once the
finalizers list is empty. As long as the finalizers list contains items, deletion is blocked.
Once the deletionTimestamp is set, this value may not be unset or be set further into the
future, although it may be shortened or the resource may be deleted prior to this time.
For example, a user may request that a pod is deleted in 30 seconds. The Kubelet will react
by sending a graceful termination signal to the containers in the pod. After that 30 seconds,
the Kubelet will send a hard termination signal (SIGKILL) to the container and after cleanup,
remove the pod from the API. In the presence of network partitions, this object may still
exist after this timestamp, until an administrator or automated process can determine the
resource is fully terminated.
If not set, graceful deletion of the object has not been requested.

Populated by the system when a graceful deletion is requested.
Read-only.
More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#metadata
+optional

deletionGracePeriodSeconds.title:
Number of seconds allowed for this object to gracefully terminate before
it will be removed from the system. Only set when deletionTimestamp is also set.
May only be shortened.
Read-only.
+optional

labels.title:
Map of string keys and values that can be used to organize and categorize
(scope and select) objects. May match selectors of replication controllers
and services.
More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/labels
+optional

annotations.title:
Annotations is an unstructured key value map stored with a resource that may be
set by external tools to store and retrieve arbitrary metadata. They are not
queryable and should be preserved when modifying objects.
More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/annotations
+optional

ownerReferences.title:
List of objects depended by this object. If ALL objects in the list have
been deleted, this object will be garbage collected. If this object is managed by a controller,
then an entry in this list will point to this controller, with the controller field set to true.
There cannot be more than one managing controller.
+optional
+patchMergeKey=uid
+patchStrategy=merge

finalizers.title:
Must be empty before the object is deleted from the registry. Each entry
is an identifier for the responsible component that will remove the entry
from the list. If the deletionTimestamp of the object is non-nil, entries
in this list can only be removed.
Finalizers may be processed and removed in any order.  Order is NOT enforced
because it introduces significant risk of stuck finalizers.
finalizers is a shared field, any actor with permission can reorder it.
If the finalizer list is processed in order, then this can lead to a situation
in which the component responsible for the first finalizer in the list is
waiting for a signal (field value, external system, or other) produced by a
component responsible for a finalizer later in the list, resulting in a deadlock.
Without enforced ordering finalizers are free to order amongst themselves and
are not vulnerable to ordering changes in the list.
+optional
+patchStrategy=merge

clusterName.title:
The name of the cluster which the object belongs to.
This is used to distinguish resources with same name and namespace in different clusters.
This field is not set anywhere right now and apiserver is going to ignore it if set in create or update request.
+optional

managedFields.description:
ManagedFields maps workflow-id and version to the set of fields
that are managed by that workflow. This is mostly for internal
housekeeping, and users typically shouldn't need to set or
understand this field. A workflow can be the user's name, a
controller's name, or the name of a specific apply path like
"ci-cd". The set of fields is always in the version that the
workflow used when modifying the object.

+optional

v1ObjectMeta.description:
ObjectMeta is metadata that all persisted resources must have, which includes all objects
users must create.

kind.title:
Kind of the referent.
More info: https://git.k8s.io/community/contributors/devel/sig-architecture/api-conventions.md#types-kinds

name.title:
Name of the referent.
More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#names

uid.title:
UID of the referent.
More info: http://kubernetes.io/docs/user-guide/identifiers#uids

controller.title:
If true, this reference points to the managing controller.
+optional

blockOwnerDeletion.title:
If true, AND if the owner has the "foregroundDeletion" finalizer, then
the owner cannot be deleted from the key-value store until this
reference is removed.
Defaults to false.
To set this field, a user needs "delete" permission of the owner,
otherwise 422 (Unprocessable Entity) will be returned.
+optional

v1OwnerReference.description:
OwnerReference contains enough information to let you identify an owning
object. An owning object must be in the same namespace as the dependent, or
be cluster-scoped, so there is no namespace field.

seconds.description:
Represents seconds of UTC time since Unix epoch
1970-01-01T00:00:00Z. Must be from 0001-01-01T00:00:00Z to
9999-12-31T23:59:59Z inclusive.

nanos.description:
Non-negative fractions of a second at nanosecond resolution. Negative
second values with fractions must still have non-negative nanos values
that count forward in time. Must be from 0 to 999,999,999
inclusive. This field may be limited in precision depending on context.

v1Time.description:
Time is a wrapper around time.Time which supports correct
marshaling to YAML and JSON.  Wrappers are provided for many
of the factory methods that the time package offers.

+protobuf.options.marshal=false
+protobuf.as=Timestamp
+protobuf.options.(gogoproto.goproto_stringer)=false

startTime.title:
The time when the build started.
+optional

spanID.title:
The log span where the build logs are stored in the logstore.
+optional

v1alpha1UIBuildRunning.description: UIBuildRunning respresents an in-progress build/update in the user interface.

error.title:
A non-empty string if the build failed with an error.
+optional

warnings.title:
A list of warnings encountered while running the build.
These warnings will also be printed to the build's log.
+optional

startTime.title:
The time when the build started.
+optional

finishTime.title:
The time when the build finished.
+optional

spanID.title:
The log span where the build logs are stored in the logstore.
+optional

isCrashRebuild.title:
A crash rebuild happens when Tilt live-updated a container, then
the pod crashed, wiping out the live-updates. Tilt does a full
build+deploy to reset the pod state to what's on disk.
+optional

v1alpha1UIBuildTerminated.description: UIBuildRunning respresents a finished build/update in the user interface.

location.description: Location associates the button with another component for layout.

text.description: Text to appear on the button itself or as hover text (depending on button location).

iconName.description:
IconName is a Material Icon to appear next to button text or on the button itself (depending on button location).

Valid values are icon font ligature names from the Material Icons set.
See https://fonts.google.com/icons for the full list of available icons.

If both IconSVG and IconName are specified, IconSVG will take precedence.

+optional

iconSVG.description:
IconSVG is an SVG to use as the icon to appear next to button text or on the button itself (depending on button
location).

This should be an <svg> element scaled for a 24x24 viewport.

If both IconSVG and IconName are specified, IconSVG will take precedence.

+optional

v1alpha1UIButtonSpec.title: UIButtonSpec defines the desired state of UIButton

lastClickedAt.description:
LastClickedAt is the timestamp of the last time the button was clicked.

If the button has never clicked before, this will be the zero-value/null.

v1alpha1UIButtonStatus.title: UIButtonStatus defines the observed state of UIButton

componentID.description:
ComponentID is the identifier of the parent component to associate this component with.

For example, this is a resource name if the ComponentType is Resource.

componentType.description: ComponentType is the type of the parent component.

v1alpha1UIComponentLocation.description: UIComponentLocation specifies where to put a UI component.

v1alpha1UIFeatureFlag.description:
Configures Tilt to enable non-default features (e.g., experimental or
deprecated).

The Tilt features controlled by this are generally in an unfinished state,
and not yet documented.

As a Tilt user, you donâ€™t need to worry about this unless something
else directs you to (e.g., an experimental feature doc, or a conversation
with a Tilt contributor).

v1alpha1UIResource.description:
UIResource represents per-resource status data for rendering the web UI.

Treat this as a legacy data structure that's more intended to make transition
easier rather than a robust long-term API.

+k8s:openapi-gen=true

podName.description:
The name of the active pod.

The active pod tends to be what Tilt defaults to for port-forwards,
live-updates, etc.
+optional

podCreationTime.title:
The creation time of the active pod.
+optional

podUpdateStartTime.title:
The last update time of the active pod
+optional

podStatus.title:
The status of the active pod.
+optional

podStatusMessage.title:
Extra error messaging around the current status of the active pod.
+optional

allContainersReady.title:
Whether all the containers in the pod are currently healthy
and have passed readiness checks.
+optional

spanID.title:
The span where this pod stores its logs in the Tilt logstore.
+optional

displayNames.title:
The list of all resources deployed in the Kubernetes deploy
for this resource.
+optional

v1alpha1UIResourceKubernetes.description: UIResourceKubernetes contains status information specific to Kubernetes.

name.title:
The display label on a URL.
+optional

v1alpha1UIResourceLink.description: UIResourceLink represents a link assocatiated with a UIResource.

pid.title:
The PID of the actively running local command.
+optional

isTest.title:
Whether this represents a test job.
+optional

v1alpha1UIResourceLocal.description: UIResourceLocal contains status information specific to local commands.

v1alpha1UIResourceSpec.description:
UIResourceSpec is an empty struct.
UIResource is a kludge for making Tilt's internal status readable, not
for specifying behavior.

lastDeployTime.title:
The last time this resource was deployed.
+optional

triggerMode.title:
Bit mask representing whether this resource is run when:
1) When a file changes
2) When the resource initializes
+optional

currentBuild.title:
The currently running build, if any.
+optional

pendingBuildSince.title:
When the build was put in the pending queue.
+optional

hasPendingChanges.title:
True if the build was put in the pending queue due to file changes.
+optional

runtimeStatus.description:
The RuntimeStatus is a simple, high-level summary of the runtime state of a server.

Not all resources run servers.
+optional

updateStatus.description:
The UpdateStatus is a simple, high-level summary of any update tasks to bring
the resource up-to-date.

If the resource runs a server, this may include both build tasks and live-update
syncing.
+optional

specs.title:
Information about all the target specs that this resource summarizes.
+optional

queued.title:
Queued is a simple indicator of whether the resource is queued for an update.
+optional

order.description:
Order expresses the relative order of resources in the UI when they're not
otherwise sorted. Lower integers go first. When two resources have the same
order, they should be sorted by name.

When UIResources are generated from the Tiltfile, we use the order they
were added to the Tiltfile for the Order field.

+optional

v1alpha1UIResourceStatus.title: UIResourceStatus defines the observed state of UIResource

hasLiveUpdate.title:
Whether the target has a live update assocated with it.
+optional

v1alpha1UIResourceTargetSpec.description: UIResourceTargetSpec represents the spec of a build or deploy that a resource summarizes.

v1alpha1UISession.description:
UISession represents global status data for rendering the web UI.

Treat this as a legacy data structure that's more intended to make transition
easier rather than a robust long-term API.

Per-resource status data should be stored in UIResource.

+k8s:openapi-gen=true

v1alpha1UISessionSpec.description:
UISessionSpec is an empty struct.
UISession is a kludge for making Tilt's internal status readable, not
for specifying behavior.

featureFlags.title:
FeatureFlags reports a list of experimental features that have been
enabled.
+optional

needsAnalyticsNudge.title:
NeedsAnalyticsNudge reports whether the UI hasn't opted in or out
of analytics, and the UI should nudge them to do so.
+optional

runningTiltBuild.title:
RunningTiltBuild reports the currently running version of tilt
that this UI is talking to.
+optional

suggestedTiltVersion.title:
SuggestedTiltVersion tells the UI the recommended version for this
user. If the version is different than what's running, the UI
may display a prompt to upgrade.
+optional

versionSettings.title:
VersionSettings indicates whether version updates have been enabled/disabled
from the Tiltfile.
+optional

tiltCloudUsername.title:
TiltCloudUsername reports the username if the user is signed into
TiltCloud.
+optional

tiltCloudTeamName.title:
TiltCloudUsername reports the human-readable team name if the user is
signed into TiltCloud and the Tiltfile declares a team.
+optional

tiltCloudSchemeHost.title:
TiltCloudSchemeHost reports the base URL of the Tilt Cloud instance
associated with this Tilt process. Usually https://cloud.tilt.dev
+optional

tiltCloudTeamID.title:
TiltCloudTeamID reports the unique team id if the user is signed into
TiltCloud and the Tiltfile declares a team.
+optional

fatalError.title:
A FatalError is an error that forces Tilt to stop its control loop.
The API server will stay up and continue to serve the UI, but
no further builds will happen.
+optional

tiltStartTime.title:
The time that this instance of tilt started.
Clients can use this to determine if the API server has restarted
and all the objects need to be refreshed.
+optional

tiltfileKey.title:
An identifier for the Tiltfile that is running.
Clients can use this to store data associated with a particular
project in LocalStorage or other persistent storage.
+optional

v1alpha1UISessionStatus.title: UISessionStatus defines the observed state of UISession

to_checkpoint.title: The to_checkpoint on the received LogList

tilt_start_time.description:
Allows us to synchronize on a running Tilt intance,
so we can tell when we're talking to the same Tilt.

webviewAckWebsocketRequest.description:
NOTE(nick): This is obsolete.

Our websocket service has two kinds of messages:
1) On initialization, we send down the complete view state
2) On every change, we send down the resources that have
   changed since the last send().

span_id.description: The span id for this build record's logs in the main logstore.

span_id.title: The span id for this pod's logs in the main logstore

webviewLogLevel.description:
- NONE: For backwards-compatibility, the int value doesn't say
anything about relative severity.

from_checkpoint.description:
[from_checkpoint, to_checkpoint)

An interval of [0, 0) means that the server isn't using
the incremental load protocol.

An interval of [-1, -1) means that the server doesn't have new logs
to send down.
from_checkpoint.title:
from_checkpoint and to_checkpoint express an interval on the
central log-store, with an inclusive start and an exclusive end

anchor.description:
When we store warnings in the LogStore, we break them up into lines and
store them as a series of line segments. 'anchor' marks the beginning of a
series of logs that should be kept together.

Anchor warning1, line1
       warning1, line2
Anchor warning2, line1

fields.description:
Context-specific optional fields for a log segment.
Used for experimenting with new types of log metadata.

webviewTargetType.title: Correspond to implementations of the TargetSpec interface

DEPRECATED_log_timestamps.description:
We used to have a setting that allowed users to dynamically
prepend timestamps in logs.

tilt_start_time.description:
Allows us to synchronize on a running Tilt intance,
so we can tell when Tilt restarted.

tiltfile_key.title: an identifier for the tiltfile that is running, so that the web ui can store data per tiltfile

is_complete.description:
indicates that this view is a complete representation of the app
if false, this view just contains deltas from a previous view.

webviewView.description:
1) On initialization, we send down the complete view state
   (TiltStartTime, UISession, UIResources, and LogList)

2) On every change, we send down the resources that have
   changed since the last send().
   (new logs and any updated UISession/UIResource objects).

All other fields are obsolete, but are needed for deserializing
old snapshots.
webviewView.title: Our websocket service has two kinds of View messages:
